Title:
Bat genomes reveal accelerated evolution in innate immunity
and the DNA damage checkpoint
Keywords:
bat phylogenesis, flight, immunity, hibernation,
echolocation
Abstract:
Bats are the only mammals capable of flight and are
notorious reservoir hosts for some of the worldâs most highly pathogenic
viruses, including Nipah, Hendra, Ebola and SARS. To identify genetic
changes associated with the development of these traits, we performed
whole genome sequencing and comparative analyses of two distantly
related bat species, fruit bat Pteropus alecto and insectivorous Myotis
davidii. We discovered an unexpected concentration of positively
selected genes in the DNA damage checkpoint and NF-ÎºB pathways that may
be related to the origin of flight, as well as expansion and contraction
of gene families relevant to innate immunity. Comparison of bat genomes
with other mammalian species has provided new insight into bat biology
and evolution.
